results.title: The Pre-Raphaelite revolt
results.creator_credit: David Thompson, Anne Balfour Fraser and Samaritan Films
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the philosophy of the Pre-Raphaelite painters, who made a concerted effort to “save” art by returning to the “truth of nature”. The narration and the visual content evoke the era of the Pre-Raphaelite in around 1848. The film helps to clarify the individual approaches of the painters and how they achieved the return to nature. Narrated by John Wood and poems of Tennyson, D.G. Rossetti and Christina Rossetti read by Freda Dowie. A fasinating and interesting film.

results.title: The Making of a live television show
results.brief_description: Production of a live television show, from the first meeting of the writers to the dance rehearsal, to the final performance. Shows the pressure on the director and points out that a television presentation requires much pre-planning and work. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Making of 'Silent Running'
results.creator_credit: Chuck Barbee, Thomas Piskura and Chuck Barbee Productions
results.brief_description: Presents a behind-the-scenes look at the people and technology needed to produce the film “Silent running”. Gives a close look at the work of director Douglas Trumbull, star Bruce Dern, singer Joan Baez, the editor, cameraman and others. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Ingmar Bergman
results.creator_credit: Stig Bjorkman, Stattan Hedqvist and Svenska filminstitutet
results.brief_description: Ingmar Bergman is widely acknowledged by film critics as adopting an intellectual stance towards film making, as well as being one of the great directors of actors. This documentary includes clips from his films and indicates his working relationships with actors. The film also brings out the requirements involved in being a film director. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Hollywood: the golden years
results.creator_credit: David L. Wolper and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description: Traces the growth of the motion picture industry from nickelodeon days to the advent of sound. Features Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, Mary Pickford and many others. Much of the content is linked to the work of the leading screen directors of the silent era: D.W. Griffith, Mack Sennett and Cecil B. De Mille. Narrated by Gene Kelly. Suitable for upper secondary level

results.title: A Study in wet
results.brief_description: There is no narration in this study of the many forms of water. A bright-colored surfboard is reflected in rippling water and the image returns as a kind of punctuation mark throughout the film. The abstract patterns of water and spray introduce other uses of water and the film ends in a climactic surfing sequence with experts riding giant waves.

results.title: Star seekers
results.creator_credit: John Wilson, Fine Arts and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: This film gives a rather brief and superficial account of man’s view of the universe. The Greek explanations in terms of the elements are discussed, as are the contributions and theories of Pythagoras, Ptolemy, Copernicus, Kepler, Newton and Kant. Also introduces the theories of Einstein and Hoyle.

results.title: The Emperor's new armour
results.brief_description: A humorous animated film which comments on consumerism and the arms race. Presents a story about an emperor who is persuaded by three glib salesmen to buy a made-to-measure, deluxe, drip-dry, stainless steel, suit of ‘soft’ armour which he does not need and which his kingdom cannot afford.

results.title: Mountain family in Europe
results.brief_description: Passing through a mountain valley to a small village, the camera follows a tractor up the hillsides to the summer grazing area. Here the summer activities are seen: the milking of cows by hand, the making of cheese and the cutting, drying and collection of hay. No commentary. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Madeline
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Ludwig Bemelman and told in rhyming verse. It depicts Madeline, the smallest and most fearless of twelve girls in a Paris school, having her appendix out in a hospital full of toys, books and flowers. Music by David Raksin, animation by Bill Melendez and Frank Smith, narration by Gladys Holland. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.
